column1: It's nice and bright today, isn't it?
column2: Yeah. The autumn is marvelous here.
column3: How about winter?
column4: That's a hard time. The air is cold and damp, and the road is often icy.
column5: It's boring, right?
column6: Sure.
column7: Do you get much rain during the summer?
column8: Plenty. We never worry about lack of rainwater in our area.
column9: So you should bring an umbrella often.
column10: That's right.

column1: Does he know that he has already at his wits' end?
column2: I think he has realized that. But he is still whistling in the dark by putting up an act.
column3: He might be driven up a wall. You should not handle your relation with him with kid gloves.
column4: But when I noticed that he was left in the cold, I could not help wanting to help him to get out of the situation.

column1: I'd appreciate it if you could help me pick out a gift for my daughter.
column2: Would she be interested in a laptop?
column3: That's exactly what I was thinking of.
column4: A Mac would be an excellent gift.
column5: I like Macs. How much for a Mac?
column6: You can take a 15 - inch Pro home right now for only $ 2,100.
column7: A Mac it is. I'll take one home with me.
column8: She'll be very happy with this. And how do you plan to pay for it?
column9: I'll use my VISA, if that's okay.
column10: Now, if you'll just sign here, the Mac is all yours.
column11: Will she need anything besides what's in this box?
column12: Everything she needs is right here in the box.
column13: I appreciate your help. Maybe I'll be back for more computer stuff.
column14: Your daughter should get straight A's from now on. Good-bye.

column1: My dear, what's for supper?
column2: Red cooked carp and rape with fresh mushrooms.
column3: What about soup?
column4: Sour-peppery soup.
column5: Which condiment do you use for?
column6: I'll use ginger, garlic scallion, hot pepper and vinegar.
column7: Very good, need I help you?
column8: No, don't need, I can do myself.
column9: Thanks. I can watch TV now.
column10: But you must cook that dinner next time.
column11: Okay, I'll do it next time.

column1: Our national economy is increasing hand over fist.
column2: That ’ s really a good phenomenon to see.
column3: I hope it ’ ll continue for a long time.

column1: Ahh... What a fine day! I do feel like an outdoor exercise.
column2: How about taking a walk in the park?
column3: OK. It's delightful to have a walk in the park with the air so fresh.
column4: Oh, it's so quiet here. We have the park to ourselves, only you and me!
column5: Don't you see many people over there? Just on your left.
column6: Oh, I see them. Some are doing Taijiquan, some are performing swordplay, some are practising the Chinese Wushu.
column7: A growing keep-fit fever is sweeping over China.

column1: Hey, Tom, what to go for a run?
column2: No thanks. I like to run in the morning. I ran a couple of miles when I woke up today.
column3: I try to do that, but I can ’ t get up early enough.
column4: I couldn ’ t either at first, but you get used to it.
column5: It ’ s so hot at lunchtime ; I ’ d rather run in the morning.
column6: Well, why don ’ t you come tomorrow? I ’ ll stop by your house on my way out.
column7: I could try, but I can ’ t say for sure if I ’ ll get up in time. What time do you want to go?
column8: I ’ ll give you a call around 6 o'clock and stop by around 6 thirty.
column9: O. K., maybe if I have someone to go with, I ’ ll be able to get up in time for a jog.
column10: Great, I ’ ll see you then.
column11: See you.

column1: I'd like to buy a bottle of Centrum, a tooth brushes.
column2: Centrum? We have bottles of thirty and one hundred tablets. Which kind do you want?
column3: Give me one bottle of thirty tablets.
column4: And what kind of toothbrushes would you like?
column5: Can I have a look at them?
column6: Sure. This brand is supposed to be very good, but they're expensive. Those are new products. They come in several colors and sizes. There is also hard, soft, and medium.
column7: Are they cheaper?
column8: This one is 5 % off. That one has no reduction, but you can get a free tube of toothpaste with six toothbrushes.

column1: Could you introduce some whitening products for me?
column2: Please forgive me just being frankly, madam. You don't need whitening products because you look pretty white. But you have freckles on your face.
column3: Then what kind of product can fade freckles?
column4: I recommend Nisei products. This brand has a face cream which is effective on fading freckles.
column5: How much is it?
column6: 419 yuan.
column7: It is too expensive for me. Do you have something cheaper?
column8: I'm afraid there isn't.

column1: Where is my back pack?
column2: I don't know. Where did you leave it?
column3: I just put it on the chair a while ago, but now it's gone.
column4: Are you sure?
column5: Of course, I am sure. I bet someone stole it.
column6: Well, you should have kept an eye on it.

column1: Do you have any English newspapers?
column2: Yes, just over there.
column3: I'd like to see some Mandarin textbooks too. Do you have any?
column4: Yes, they are just next to the newspapers actually.
column5: Thank you.

column1: When is your birthday?
column2: August 1st.
column3: Do you usually have a birthday party?
column4: Yes, we do.My parents prepare dinner for me.
column5: What would you do at the party?
column6: We sing " Happy Birthday " at the party and have birthday cakes.
column7: Do you know when people began to sing the song " Happy Birthday "?
column8: Well, I don't know.
column9: Let me tell you the story.In 1892, Patty Smith Hill and Mildred Hill wrote a song called " Good Morning to you ". But later someone added the words " Happy Birthday " to their tune.
column10: So the " Happy Birthday " song has been popular since then?
column11: Yes, actually, the song has been sung since its publication in 1932.People all over the world have sung it in many different languages.

column1: Can I see some men's watches?
column2: Of course. How about this one?
column3: What functions does this watch have?
column4: It's a luminous watch with a time-reminder function.
column5: Is it waterproof?
column6: Yes, and it comes with a worldwide guarantee.
column7: I'll take it. Please set the watch for me.

column1: Did you check the internet for next week's weather forecast?
column2: I sure did. You're in luck! It's supposed to snow all week in the mountains!
column3: Yes! Somebody up there loves me! I knew it wasn't too late for snow.
column4: It is kind of strange though, to have snow in April, and so much of it.
column5: There have been so many dry winters lately that it's about time, don't you think?
column6: When you put it that way, I guess the skies can't hold out on us forever.
column7: This will be the best ski trip I've ever taken. I can't wait to use my new hoard.
column8: It will be the best as long as the weatherman is right.

column1: Hello. I want to send the computer to my sister in Shanghai by logistics transport.
column2: OK. Is it in the box? May I see it?
column3: Yes. This is the computer and this is the keyboard and the monitor.
column4: Is there anything else?
column5: There are a mouse and a camera.
column6: Is that all?
column7: Yes. How much is it to send these things to Shanghai by regular delivery?
column8: It depends on the weight of these things. Generally speaking, we will charge you ten yuan for one kilogram.
column9: I see. Can you weigh them for me, please?
column10: Please go over there to weigh them.
column11: OK. See you later.

column1: Do you mind if I come over to use your computer?
column2: No, but I have to type my paper tonight.
column3: Does that mean I can't use it tonight?
column4: You got it!

column1: Happy new year!
column2: Thank you. Same to you.
column3: Have you got any plans?
column4: I've been invited over to a friend's, and you?
column5: My roommate's having a party.

column1: I remember you said that you like China because it has cheap beers.
column2: Yes, unbelievably cheap. Carlsborg is less than $ 1.
column3: Why do you drink? I mean, where does drinking get you?
column4: It's fashionable.
column5: Come on, you don't even know that blinds following is a sign of immaturity.
column6: Mary, it's not about the blind following. What matter is I enjoy in drinking. It's like when you get off of work. You're so tired. You need to get relaxed. You can't just turn on the TV and keep watch the programs until you fall asleep. You need to make your after work time more fun.
column7: How? By drinking?
column8: Drinking is just part of it. I mean, you have a bunch of friends coming by and having fun. You drink and talk. And the more you drink, the more you talk. It makes me so relaxed.
column9: When did you begin to drink?
column10: It's a long time ago. When I first went to a bar to pick up girls there, I saw the most beautiful girl sitting and sipping a coke. Then I went up to her and said' can I buy you a drink?'
column11: And then?
column12: Then I talked to her and got her number. You know what? When you don't know what to say? Just drink.
column13: So you get drunk every day?

column1: That was a great dinner. I didn't know that you knew how yo cook.
column2: I'm glad you liked it. Are you ready for dessert?
column3: I don't know. I'm pretty full. What are we having?
column4: I made strawberry shortcake.
column5: Ooh, that's my favorite. Maybe I'll have a small slice.
column6: Great. Would you like coffee or tea with that?
column7: I'll have a cup of tea.
column8: Do you take cream or sugar with your tea?
column9: Actually, could I have some milk with that?
column10: Definitely. Would you like skim or whole milk?
column11: Skim, please. That'd be very nice. Thanks... oh no. Janna, I'm so sorry, but I've got to go.
column12: What happened?
column13: I just got a message from my sister saying that she's been in a car accident. I need to go pick her up.
column14: I'll go with you. Where is she?
column15: She's on the M40, near Reading.
column16: Is she alright?
column17: I don't know, she didn't say. I'm so sorry about this.
column18: Don't worry. Family comes first. Come on, let's go.
column19: Actually, I've only got a two-seater. I'll have to go on my own.
column20: Ok. Just call me if you need anything then.

column1: Yes, madam, can I help you?
column2: I'm feeling a bit airsick.
column3: We have the medicine for that. I'll go and get it for you.
column4: Thank you. oh, can you get me some orange juice as well?
column5: Certainly. I'll be back right away.

column1: how was your education going on in Australia?
column2: I'm going to graduate this summer.
column3: where are you going to work then, in Australia or back in China?
column4: I'm planning to return to China after graduation.
column5: why are you choosing to leave a foreign country? Many people are reluctant to leave the superior living environment abroad.
column6: well, I think personal development is much more important than simply having a superior living environment.
column7: yeah, China's developing so fast and development opportunities can be found almost in every corner of the country.
column8: absolutely, many Chinese enterprises are going global, and they are in great need of excellent returnees to help them with their overseas business.
column9: the rapidly expanding economy has encouraged many students to pack their bags AMD head for home.
column10: that's right. Most of the Chinese students pursuing higher education in Australia intend to return to China.

column1: Alice, your father is amazing. He ’ s 90 years old and he lives alone in that big house.
column2: I know. He doesn ’ t like to ask anyone for help. My dad insists on paying his own bills and taking care of himself!
column3: That sounds like my Grandmother. She was always stubbornly independent.
column4: It seems that folks like my father and your grandmother are determined to be on their own.
column5: They see their independence as a kind of character strength.
column6: Sometimes they are too independent.

column1: how did your interview go?
column2: pretty well. I don't know if I'll get the promotion or not, but I feel good about it.
column3: if you get the promotion, what will your new title be?
column4: if I get the promotion, I will be a senior engineer instead of an assistant engineer.
column5: will you get a pay-raise, too?
column6: whenever you are given added responsibilities, you should get a promotion.
column7: that makes sense. Who interviewed you?
column8: my boss.
column9: what kinds of questions did she ask you?
column10: she asked me about my ability to work in a team and what I thought a good boss should be.
column11: the second one sounds rather difficult to answer. What did you tell her?
column12: I told her that I'm an excellent team player and that a good boss should treat male and female employees equally.
column13: those are good answers. How did she react?
column14: she told me that even when I become a senior engineer, I'll have to work with the assistant engineers as a team.
column15: what do you think about her as a boss?
column16: she's pretty easy to get along with. She listens to her employees and treats everyone equally.
column17: you're lucky. Not everyone has such a great boss!
column18: that's true. She's highly esteemed among everyone at my company.
column19: when you find out you get the promotion or not, let me know.

column1: You look terrific and in good shape.
column2: Thank you.
column3: How do you keep fit?
column4: I do yoga twice a weeks
column5: Yoga? It sounds interesting.
column6: It was hard at the beginning, but now feel it's really relaxing. It makes me flexible.
column7: Anything else?
column8: Yes, I often go swimming.
column9: Are you interested in swimming?
column10: Yes, I like it very much.

column1: I'm sorry, Julia! I can't get home early this evening.
column2: What? But today is my birthday!
column3: I know, darling. But I do have a lot of work to do, hope you can understand me.
column4: But Steven, why don't you ask for a leave?... Steven, why don't you speak? Are you still there?
column5: Hello, Julia? I can't hear you clearly. I'm afraid the line is out of order. Okay, B, listen! How about I hang up now and call you back later?
column6: Okay! Bye!

column1: Ladies and gentlemen, here is the Westminster Abbey. It's one of the oldest buildings in London.
column2: What a large building. Can we visit by ourselves?
column3: Of course. Take your time and enjoy your trip.
column4: Thank you. When and where shall we meet?
column5: We will meet at 5:00 right here.
column6: I see.

column1: Hello, jewelry department. How may I help you?
column2: It's me, Ali. There's this strange guy who keeps coming around. He's been here three times this week.
column3: He's probably a pervert. Just ignore him.
column4: He makes me nervous. He looks at me funny. And he never buys anything!
column5: Maybe he wants to get something for his girlfriend, but he's embarrassed.

column1: Hello! Tomorrow I'm going to need a wake-up call.
column2: Not a problem. What time shall we call you?
column3: I always hit the snooze button, so give me two calls, one at 7 and another at 7 fifteen.
column4: It'll be our pleasure. We'll call you at 7 and then at 7 fifteen.
column5: Oops, cancel that. Change the second call to 7 thirty will you, please?
column6: No sooner said than done. Can I help you with anything else?
column7: No, that's about it for now. Thanks.
column8: Okay, sir. Have a pleasant evening.

column1: Come on, fellows.Let' s enjoy my wife's cooking!
column2: Em, it's delicious!
column3: Thank you! My wife likes cooking very much.
column4: You're lucky.

column1: Good afternoon. May I help you?
column2: Yes. I'd like to check in, please.
column3: May I see your ticket and passport, please?
column4: Sure. Here they are.
column5: Please put your baggage on the scale.
column6: What's the weight limit?
column7: Thirty two kilos.
column8: I hope my baggage aren't overweight.
column9: No. They aren't.
column10: May I carry this satchel?
column11: Sure. But please attach this claim tag.
column12: OK.
column13: Here is your boarding pass.
column14: Which gate?
column15: Gate Four. Please go and have a seat in the waiting hall.
column16: Thank you.

column1: Hi, how is it going?
column2: Pretty good, Sam. Only the awful weather, you know.
column3: That ’ s right. I ’ Ve never really liked it since I got here.
column4: Me either, but I ’ m dealing with it anyway.

column1: My goodness! She is thirty seconds faster than the world record in 5000 metres race.
column2: Excuse me, what did you say?
column3: A Chinese girl has broken the world record in the Olympic Games.
column4: That's incredible. I can't believe it.
column5: You have to. It is sure.
column6: How amazing!

column1: That radio's pretty loud. Could you turn it down, please?
column2: Sorry. Was I disturbing you?
column3: Yes. And something else, please don't borrow my clothes without asking.
column4: Sorry. I guess I wasn't thinking. I won't do it again.

column1: I've come to say goodbye.
column2: When do you leave?
column3: I'm catching the eleven o'clock train.
column4: Take care of yourself and don't forget to keep in touch.
column5: Goodbye. Hope to see you again next year.

column1: Do you like that vintage clock? It's almost fifty years old.
column2: Really? It almost looks brand new. And the color designs are so retro.
column3: Well, in the fifties, that clock used to be inside a drive-in burger joint.
column4: No way! My parents used to hang out at those places.
column5: This is one of my favorite items.
column6: How did you get it?

column1: Are you going home now?
column2: No, I'm not.
column3: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
column4: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
column5: An apartment? Why?
column6: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
column7: Where are you living now?
column8: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
column9: How are you going to find an apartment?
column10: I'm going to buy a newspaper and check the classified ads.
column11: Apartments in the city are expensive.
column12: I know, but I'm going to enroll in a night school to take a course in business management.

column1: Hi, Jenny. Are you going to school now?
column2: Yup. I have English at 9 in the morning.
column3: Got any plans after the class?
column4: Not really. What about you?
column5: We will have our midterm exams next month. I plan to look for some important books and study at the library. Do you want to join me?
column6: Sure. I need to return some books. They are due today. Besides, I can also read some weekly publications, magazines and newspapers.
column7: Great. We can go to the swimming pool in the gymnasium after that.
column8: That sounds like a good idea. We can chill out a little in such a hot summer. Are you good at swimming?
column9: Well, that's a good question. I haven't swum for almost two years. I think I need more practice.
column10: Oh, it's almost 9. I need to hurry. I am running late now. See you after class in front of the library then. Bye!
column11: See you then.

column1: How do you like the food sold in this sidewalk snack booth?
column2: At least, it is better than my boxed lunch at work. I'm so fed up with the bland food. Thank you for having lunch with me!
column3: Any time. But I don't mind eating boxed lunch. The food sanitation is really good too.
column4: It's hard to believe that you like it. You are so easy to be satisfied.
column5: Hey, it's not that bad. The food is nutritious and it's really convenient. I don't want to spend too much time on eating stuff.
column6: Eating is important. You are what you eat. It's not only a daily routine.
column7: Well, will you just go back to work after lunch?
column8: No. I'm going to pay the bill for the company's lunch.
column9: But you didn't eat anything today.
column10: Well, the bill is paid by month. That's probably the only thing that I like about a take-out restaurant.
column11: All right. I'm going to the McDonald's.
column12: For what? I thought you didn't like western food.
column13: No, I never did. It's for my son. He loves it, and I made an agreement with him that he can eat it once a week.
column14: That's really smart. My son Daniel is the same with your son. I just don't get it, why all the kids prefer western food to traditional food.
column15: Me, either. But, it's for sure that the children market is a really big one.
column16: That's for sure. It's always hard for the parents to say no to their children.

column1: Are you going to the annual party? I can give you a ride if you need one.
column2: Thanks a lot. That's the favor I was going to ask you for.
column3: The pleasure is mine.

column1: What is this big box at the front door?
column2: Oh. I don't know what to do. I joined this club a long time ago and I didn't read the fine print.
column3: What did you get yourself into?
column4: I didn't realize that I have to buy something from them every six months.
column5: So, what's in the box? A fridge?
column6: It's a curio cabinet. The only thing is I don't even own those kinds of little keepsakes.
column7: I guess you'll read the fine print next time, won't you!
column8: Don't rub it in. Where am I going to put this huge thing?

column1: John, I was talking to the travel agent about where we might be taking our vacation this year.
column2: I am going fishing in Alaska with my friend, Mark.
column3: What are you talking about?
column4: What's wrong with heading out with Mark for vacation?
column5: You and I have been together for a whole year, and our vacation time should be about the two of us!
column6: Really? Who made that rule up?
column7: With that attitude, I don't really think we have much more to discuss here.
column8: That works for me!

column1: Can you recognize Mike's father in the crowd?
column2: Yes, he's holding a bunch of books.
column3: Let's run up and give him a hand.

column1: Last trip was very terrible. I hope everything will be fine this time. Don ’ t blow it.
column2: Trust me. Everything will go well.

column1: Well, sir. We are asking all our guests to wear a jacket and a tie in our restaurant.
column2: Is that so? I didn't know it. can I possibly borrow a jacket and a tie?
column3: I am sorry ; you can't borrow a jacket and a tie.
column4: Then we'll return to the hotel and come back, will you change the appointment?
column5: Certainly, what time will you come back?
column6: At 7, please.
column7: How many in your party?
column8: A party of 13.
column9: Alright, we are waiting for you at 7.

column1: You keep bowling spares but no strike.
column2: I don't know why, but I think there's something wrong with my hands. I couldn't seem to be able to control it on the first ball.
column3: I don't think it was the problem with your hands, you did several excellent spares. You have no problem with your hands.
column4: Then why couldn't I get strike on the first ball?
column5: The problem is you are too nervous. You want to have a strike so much, so you deliver the ball too hard. And when it comes to the I second roll, there's no pressure. That's why you could bowl all those spares.
column6: Really? I will try again.

column1: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
column2: I ’ m not in the mood.
column3: Why are you feeling depressed?
column4: I was told my girlfriend was speaking ill of me. That ’ s a real let-down.
column5: I don ’ t think she will do such a thing.
column6: But she did and made me disappointed.
column7: Oh, cheer up. A girlfriend is not everything.
column8: But she means a lot to me.
column9: Then forgive her mistake.

column1: I'm starving. Let's get something to eat.
column2: Can we go somewhere nearby? I don't feel like walking too far.
column3: Sure. What kind of food do you like?
column4: I mean the food for something spicy.
column5: How about some Korean food? There's a place right there on the corner.
column6: That sounds great. I love Korean food.

column1: Could you help me with these books?
column2: My hands are full. Can ’ t you see that?
column3: Please, George.
column4: All right. Just wait a minute, OK?

column1: I'm hungry. Do we have anything to eat?
column2: Just a few cookies.
column3: That's fine with me.

column1: Excuse me, did you see a set of keys?
column2: What kind of keys?
column3: Five keys and a small foot ornament.
column4: What a shame! I didn't see them.
column5: Well, can you help me look for it? That's my first time here.
column6: Sure. It's my pleasure. I'd like to help you look for the missing keys.
column7: It's very kind of you.
column8: It's not a big deal.Hey, I found them.
column9: Oh, thank God! I don't know how to thank you, guys.
column10: You're welcome.

column1: Can you give me more details on what is included in the package?
column2: Sure. The coach leaves at 6:30 a. m., in front of our office. The drive takes eight hours, with two stops to see some sights.
column3: What about the hotel accommodations?
column4: You'll be staying at Holiday Inn. It's a three-star hotel with two restaurants and a swimming pool.
column5: Great. What types of things will we do at Lushun Falls?
column6: The second day you take a four-hour city tour. In the afternoon you go on the famous boat cruise under the falls.

column1: Could you give me a taxi to pick me up and take me to the airport before 1:00 p. m.?
column2: What is your address, sir?
column3: I live in room 1106 of the Friendship Hotel.
column4: OK, someone will be there by 12:15.

column1: You are blue in the face, arn't you?
column2: The cat has eaten my fish, I'll kill it.
column3: But supposing your son killed like the fish, what do you think then?
column4: I'll beat him.
column5: So beat the cat, but don't kill it.

column1: Hello. I have a room booked for tonight, the 15th.
column2: Alright and what is your name, please?
column3: It's Marcia Gleason.
column4: Ah, yes, here you are Ms. Gleason. You reserved a single, right?
column5: Yes, a single, thanks.
column6: Do you mind being next to the elevator?
column7: Actually, I'd prefer not to be.

column1: It's crunch time, isn't it? I wasn't nervous before the meeting, but now I am.
column2: No kidding. Time is running out.
column3: It would help to bring in a couple more troubleshooters.
column4: Vince says he can't afford anybody else. We're got to come through.
column5: Do you think we'll make it?
column6: I guess we'll either make it, or we won't.

column1: Can I help you?
column2: Yes.When is the next train to New York City?
column3: Let me see... the train to New York City... here it is... daily except Sunday at ten thirty, twelve twenty and fifteen ten.
column4: Aren't there any trains before ten thirty?
column5: Sorry, not before ten thirty.
column6: Then one to New York at ten thirty.
column7: One way or round trip?
column8: One way.
column9: A soft seat or hard one?
column10: How much is a soft?
column11: 15 dollars.And for a hard one, only 6 dollars.
column12: Then one hard seat, please.
column13: OK.Here is your change.The train leaves on platform 8.

column1: No. 164 in lane 3 achieved 11' 16 in the 100 meter dash. Isn't that something?
column2: Yeah. He's the most experienced athlete in the field.
column3: He won the first place!
column4: Good boy!

column1: I have an appointment for half past one.
column2: What can I help you with?
column3: Well, I have a problem with my class schedule.
column4: What is it?
column5: It seems that I've been given two classes scheduled at the same time.
column6: I can understand the problem with that.
column7: Is there any way that you can fix my schedule?
column8: No problem, do you want those classes still?
column9: Yes, I do.
column10: Let me see if I can find one of these classes on another day.
column11: Thank you very much.

column1: What would be a good day to finally move into the house?
column2: You can pick up your keys on Tuesday night. When you actually move in is up to you.
column3: Will the electricity and water be on, or do we need to do something to get it turned on?
column4: Make sure that you transfer the utilities to your name and tell them when you will be moving in.
column5: The carpet needs to be cleaned, and I want to paint the walls a different color.
column6: An empty house is easier to paint and clean. Take a few days to take care of those things before you start moving your furniture in.
column7: I want my appliances to be delivered as we are moving into the house.
column8: I think that will work out just fine. It will help when you move your groceries in and need to keep them cold.
column9: Would you be willing to help me do a few things on the day I move in?
column10: My grandmother needs me to help her trim her roses that day.

column4: Have a heart, honey. You know I am trying hard to quit drinking, don't you? Just give me one more chance, please!

column8: Let's go into the restaurant and find a table to order some food.
column9: Wait. Let me tell the lady what we would like to order in front of the seafood fridge first.
column10: OK. I will wait for you inside the restaurant
column11: Do you think we should try some deep fried oysters?

column1: I am considering going for the new job that was posted yesterday.
column2: Are you certain that that is what you want to do?
column3: It may not be the best choice for me, but I am considering it.
column4: Why do you think that this would be a good move?
column5: I believe that this job would allow me to move up but might be a little boring for me.
column6: Yes, there are always pros and cons to making a career change.
column7: Also, the matter of pay is also a consideration.
column8: I think the slight pay decrease might be worth it. The benefits are much better.
column9: Yes, sometimes giving up a little to move forward is the best choice.
column10: I think you should definitely apply for the position.

column6: Well, I'll be back in a minute.

column1: Good coming, sir. What can I do for you?

column4: What's the 30 yuan for?
column5: This is the charge for your laundry service on Nov. 20thA
column6: But I did't take any laundry service during my stay here. I think you have added someone else's.
column7: Would you mind waiting a moment while we check it with the department concerned?
column8: I don't mind waiting as long as we get this straightened out.
column9: I'm very sorry, Mr. Bob. There has been a mistake. We'll correct the bill.
column10: It doesn't matter. Here is the money.
column11: Thank you very much. Hope to see you again.

column1: Hi, sorry to have kept you waiting.
column2: That's all right.
column3: How are you?
column4: Fine, and you?

column1: Hey, Susan. Have you got a sec? I have some questions about my paycheck.
column2: You bet, Emily. Pull up a chair.
column3: Well, this is my first paycheck here in the States and there are a few things I don't understand. First of all, what is this FICA, and SUI Y tax, and why are there deductions both for Medicare and for my health insurance plan?
column4: OK, let's start from the top of your pay stub. This number here represents your gross pay.
column5: Then here we have a series of deductions. First off are the federal ones. FICA stands for Federal Insurance Contribution Act, or something like that. It's your federal income tax. And then there's Social Security and Medicare, which are both federal programs to help you out after you retire or if you were unable to work.
column6: All right, I see. So the Medicare isn't actually a health insurance I can use now.
column7: That's right. Below the federal deductions are the state deductions. There's the state income tax, and then this SUI / SDI tax you were asking about is paying into an unemployment and disability fund that our state has set up, but you can see it's a pretty small quantity that they take.
column8: Yeah, I don't mind giving them a dollar fifty for that. So there are two separate income taxes — one at a state level and one at a federal level?
column9: That's right. Not all states have an income tax. Some use higher property taxes or sales taxes instead.
column10: I see. All right, well I think everything else I can figure out on my own. The deductions for health insurance and my 401 ( K ) are pretty self-explanatory. Thanks for your help, Susan.
column11: No problem! All those deductions do add up, and nobody's net pay is as high as they'd like. I can understand why you'd want some explanation.
column12: Yeah, I guess it's the same in the UK, I just never paid much attention. See you later!

column1: Do you know who ’ s just got married? Old Mc Donald.

column3: He ’ s nearly 90.

column5: I am. Whatsmore, his wife is 84.
column6: Is she really?
column7: Yes, she is. And guess what, he is her sixth husband.
column8: Really? Quite a woman, isn ’ t she?

column1: It ’ s rather cold. Isn ’ t it

column4: That ’ s a good idea

column6: It ’ s mild. but it ’ s not always pleasant.

column8: I like spring. The days are long and the nights are short. The flowers in blew. We go on picnics

column1: Ok, so who are we going to invite to our dinner party?
column2: Well, we have the Thompsons, the Greens, and the Anderson, about twelve people total.
column3: Don't forget my friend Andy from the office. He has nothing to do on Friday, so I invited him over.
column4: But that makes thirteen people! We can't have thirteen people for dinner on Friday!
column5: Why can't we?
column6: It's an old superstition. If we have thirteen people at the table, then it means bad luck. Can Andy bring a date?
column7: I'm not sure. He just broke up with his girlfriend recently, and I don't think he's in the mood to start again so soon.
column8: But we can't have thirteen for dinner!
column9: I think you're making a mountain out of a molehill. It's only a superstition. It really doesn't mean anything.
column10: Absolutely not! I refuse to have thirteen people for dinner on Friday!
column11: Ok, ok. I'll ask my sister to come. That way we'll have fourteen for dinner.
column12: That's better.

column1: Are you ready for your first driving lesson?
column2: Yes. Which one is the brake again?
column3: The pedal on your left is the brake and the one on your right is the gas.
column4: I ’ m glad this car is an automatic. I don't like having to change gears.
column5: Automatics are very simple to drive. The first thing you should do is put your seat belt on.
column6: You should also put yours on. you never know what will happen with me in the driver ’ s seat!
column7: Very funny. Next you should check your side mirrors and your rear view mirror. Can you see out of them?
column8: I can ’ t see anything out of the side mirror on your side of the car. Could you move it forward a bit, please?
column9: How ’ s that?
column10: That ’ s better. Now what?
column11: Check your petrol situation.
column12: The tank is almost empty. I guess I ’ ll drive to the petrol station to fill it up.
column13: That ’ s a good idea. Put your keys in the ignition, start it up, put the car in reserve, wait for the road to be clear, and then back out of the driveway.
column14: I got it. Don ’ t worry. I ’ ll get you there in one piece.
column15: Remember, no honking this time. The horn is only for emergencies!
column16: Why does that cop car behind me have its red lights on?

column1: What's the matter?

column6: Just fill it up with Regular, Unleaded, please.

column4: no way. I will be scared out of my wits.

column6: Hey, how could you like to taste my fist?

column8: Um, let me see, romance, comedy. documentary, action, science fiction, animated and so on.
column9: that is to say, you like all genres except for horror movies.
column10: yeah. It seems like we don't speak the same language as far as movies are concerned.
column11: not quite. I also greatly enjoy romance and comedy.
column12: the Notebook is this type of movie.
column13: really? I haven't heard of it.
column14: well then, this could be a nice opportunity to enjoy it together. I bet you'd love it.
column15: Ok. I can't wait to see it. Let's go!

column1: Ah! No! Damn it!
column2: It's a blackout. Now I can't see Seinfeld.
column3: So what? I just lost one hour's worth of work.
column4: Really? How could you do that? Don't you save every couple minutes?
column5: No, I didn't save this time.Damn it! And I'm sick of writing this paper. Now I have to write it all over again too.
column6: I've had that problem too many times. So I learned to save.When I'm writing something, I save every three sentences or so. I don't want to lose anything.
column7: I hate computers. Sometimes I think they cause more trouble than they're worth.
column8: What are we going to do now?
column9: I don't know. I feel like going out.
column10: I wonder how much of the city is down.
column11: It doesn't matter. I still can go out and buy a beer.
column12: Maybe. But if there's a blackout, probably the pubs are closed.And besides, I know you have a political science exam tomorrow. I thought you had a lot of reading to do.
column13: Yes, that's true. Damn! I just lost half my paper, and now I can't even do my homework.This is a bad time for this to happen.
column14: I have a flashlight in my closet. If you want to use that to read, you can.
column15: Thanks. I think I will try. Where are you going?
column16: I like your idea of getting a beer. I think I'll go out myself.
column17: Maybe we can trade.Why don't you stay here and read for my exam, and I'll go drink beer?
column18: No, it just won't work.If I read for your exam, you won't know the answers tomorrow. I will.
column19: So? You can go to the class for me.Just write my name on the exam book and take the exam. Why not?
column20: How many students are in the class?
column22: So it won't work, old buddy. They'll see that I'm not you. Sorry.

column1: So click here, then up to the top.
column2: Er... Hum... Got it.
column3: Then open that window. Yeah, that one.
column4: Right!
column5: And that's it. You're done.
column6: I see what you mean. That was pretty easy after all.

column1: So it is hard to be a black student on campus?
column2: Yes, in many ways it is. There are many stereotypes I have to deal with in my daily life.
column3: Stereotypes? Like what?
column4: Well, like since I'm black, I must like rap music, come from the inner city, or play basketball well.
column5: I do know you like rap music, but the other two are definitely false. I ’ Ve seen you play basketball.
column6: Hey! But that's not the only problem. There's also the affirmative action stigma.
column7: You mean that people look down upon you because they think you're in school because of a quota? That's not true at all, you're really a smart guy.
column8: I know that, but some people don't think like that. And I get problems from teachers as well.
column9: Teachers? I didn't think that they would be racist at all.
column10: Racist? Not exactly. It's how they look at me and ask for my opinion on a topic, as if I can speak for all black people and give them the black opinion on a subject. Suddenly I become the representative of the black race, as if we all had the same opinion.
column11: I see. It looks like there are still a lot of issues we need to work on in the US.

column1: How much does it cost to hire a motorbike?
column2: For 3 days $ 300, for 7 days $ 600.
column3: Good. I think I'll hire one for 7 days.
column4: Okay. I'll write up the paperwork.

column2: Good morning. There is no reason to miss so beautiful a morning. Is that a new bird?
column3: Oh, yes, my daughter bought it yesterday. We call her Lulu.
column4: It looks so cute. Is it a parrot?
column5: Yes. Just look at her colorful feathers. What else can it be?
column6: I see. It's interesting that there is also a parrot in my English book. His mane is Polly.
column7: Really? A foreign parrot!
column8: He can speak English, too.
column9: Maybe you can teach Lulu some English words.
column10: Lulu. Lulu. Say hello. hello. Oh, she is so smart. Good bird.

column1: It's too hot to read.
column2: We'd better go out for a walk.
column3: Which season do you like best?
column4: Spring.
column5: How about summer?
column6: I dislike it most.
column7: Why?
column8: Because the hottest season is summer in a year.
column9: But sometimes summer is more charming than the other seasons.

column1: Pardon me, but I was wondering if you could break a one.
column2: Let me look. What do you need?
column3: I need the change for the stamp machine.
column4: I think dimes and quarters will do.

column1: It ’ s so relaxing, taking a walk in the country. The air is so fresh and clean.
column2: Would you like to live in the country? I ’ m not sure I ’ d like it.
column3: I can see a lot of advantage and disadvantage. The problem is that, for me, each advantage has its own disadvantage.
column4: What do you mean?
column5: Well, I hate the noise in the city, but I love being around lost of people. The problem is that you can ’ t have lots of people and have peace and quiet. The tow just don ’ t go together.
column6: I see what you mean. I love being far away from a city, but I hate being so far away department stores and sports facilities.
column7: People can ’ t have it both ways. If you live in the country, it is often less convenient. If you live in a city, it is noisy, buy there ’ s more to do.
column8: I would love to be surrounded by hills and streams. They ’ re so much better to look at than concrete, rows of parked cars and tall buildings.
column9: I would love to hear the birds singing and feel the fresh breeze on my face. When the wind blows in the city, you get dust in your mouth and in your eyes.
column10: The view from the hill is so beautiful and relaxing. There ’ s so sign of pollution. The village looks so peaceful.
column11: Just remember that in that village there ’ s nothing to do. There ’ s not even a pub or restaurant. There ’ s just one small shop with a poor selection of goods.
column12: You ’ re right. I would have to travel to the city at least once a week to go shopping and see friends. I would hate living in the country!

column1: Would you mind if I ask you whether you are married or not?
column2: To be frank, I was married once, and now I'm single.
column3: Do you mean you got a divorce?
column4: Yes, my first marriage was a failure.

column1: Welcome to Al ’ s Garage. What seems to be the problem?
column2: No problem at all! I am taking a long road trip and I want to make sure my car is in good mechanical condition.
column3: Very wise decision. When was the last time you had a tune up?
column4: Not that long ago, I think it was four months ago.
column5: We usually recommend that you bring your car in every five thousand kilometers.
column6: Why? I mean, what exactly do you do to a car that you need to check it so often?
column7: First of all, we change the motor oil and oil filter. If you don ’ t do this, it can cause your engine to wear faster and that means you would probably have to change the pistons and intake valves.
column8: I see. What else?
column9: We also check your spark plugs, fuel filter, and other oil levels such as hydraulic fluid. We also check the clutch and brakes to determine when you will need new ones.
column10: Ok, well, when you put it that way, it doesn ’ t seem like a waste of time and money.
column11: Trust me, regular tune ups will keep your car running smoothly and avoid break downs.

column1: Why aren't you at work?
column2: I called in sick.

column1: When was America discovered, Tony?
column2: I'm not certain. Do you know?
column3: America was discovered by Christopher Columbus in 1492.
column4: In a way that's right. But the Vikings travelled there long beforeColumbus. And what about the Red Indians?
column5: All right. Ask me a question now.
column6: Who invented the electric light bulb?
column7: That's easy. It was invented by Edison.
column8: Correct. Now for a harder question. Who will be the first men on Mars?
column9: I can't answer that. But I think Mars will be visited by men before theed of this century.
column10: Ask me a question now.
column11: All right. What is the nearest planet to the sun?
column12: That's easy. It's.. er. Venus. NO. Pluto. No. Wait a minute. It's Anthe tip of my tongue. Oh dear, what is the nearest planet to the sun?

column1: Julia, I apologize to you for what I have done. Please forgive me.
column2: I've already forgiven you. Actually, I also owe you an apology. I was so rude to you that day.
column3: It does ’ t matter. I know that people are easy to get mad when they're tired.
column4: Thanks for your understanding.
column5: You're welcome. Happy couples need mutual understanding.

column1: Your daughter will be back soon. I'm going to start making dinner. You can just watch some TV in TV room if you like. We just bought a new TV with a LCD screen. The remote control is on the coffee table next to the armchair.
column2: Would you mind if I helped out in the kitchen instead? I do enjoy cooking.
column3: This is supposed to be your vacation ; we'd like you to just relax.
column4: Cooking makes me feel relaxed. So, what are we cooking?
column5: Ok, well, we're going to make a pan of lasagne, a salad, and some garlic bread. Here's the recipe. Do you want to get the ingredients we need out of the cupboard?
column6: Sure. We should probably pre-heat the oven right away, too.
column7: That's a good idea. Can you set the oven to 200 degrees Celsius?
column8: That's a bit high for lasagne. I'll just set it at 180 degree and we can take it from there.
column9: Fine. I'll just get out the casserole dish, the saucepan, the salad bowl, and the baking sheet.
column10: You know, I could do this myself. Why don't you go get the screwdriver and the pliers and go fix the vacuum cleaner so it works better?
column11: I don't think it's broken.
column12: Well, if it's not broken, then you need to learn how to vacuum better, because it doesn't look like you've vacuumed for ages!
column13: Fine. I'll go vacuum. Let me know if you need any other help.

column1: I come to try my new suit. Here's the receipt.
column2: Yes, please wait a minute. I'll fetch it for you. Here it is. Please try it on and take a look at the mirror. How do you like it?
column3: Aren't the trousers a little too long?
column4: If you think so, we'll shorten the legs a bit. It'll take about twenty minutes.
column5: Very well. Thank you.
column6: You're welcome, sir.

column1: Fancy seeing you here 。 Lily.
column2: Yeah.What a surprise!
column3: How's everything going?
column4: Fine.thanks.

column1: I think I may rent this apartment from you.

column4: The rent is $ 1050 every month.

column7: I can afford about $ 800 a month for rent.
column8: That ’ s not high enough.
column9: How much more are you thinking?
column10: I can let it go at $ 900 a month.
column11: That ’ s almost perfect.
column12: I can live with that too.

column3: Quite delicious, especially the pepper steak.
column4: I'm glad you like it. It's $ 60 in all.
column5: Here is the money.

column1: Betty, would you please read this letter of application I've just written? I'd like to have your opinion.
column2: I'd be glad to tell you what I think.
column3: Good! I'm interested in your advice.
column4: If I were you, I would change the beginning. You should write about your education first because we like to judge a man by his abilities.
column5: Good idea, Betty. What would you think about the second part?
column6: I think it's too short. You'd better say something about your work experience.
column7: You're right, I'll change it. How about the last part?
column8: Very good. But you should talk about your family, too.
column9: I agree. I appreciate your helping me.

column1: Good morning. Welcome to Time After Time Watches.
column2: I'd like to buy a watch.
column3: Well, you've come to the right place. What kind of watch are you looking for?
column4: Well, I'm not sure. Let's see. How much is this one?
column5: Hmm... This Rolex? $ 1,000.
column6: Oh. I don't think I can afford that. How about this one?
column7: This one is $ 500.
column8: Wow. That's too much for me. Don't you have anything cheaper?

column1: Honey, I ’ ll be right back!
column2: Where are you going?
column3: I told you already! I ’ m going to get my nails done.
column4: Again? You just went last week! You spend more time at the nail salon than you do here at home! Honestly, why do you need a manicure every week?
column5: Well, first of all, I like to pamper myself, and my nails look great. You should come with me!
column6: Why? I don ’ t want to have nail polish or anything like that!
column7: They don ’ t only paint my nails! The manicurist will remove my cuticles, file my nails, and apply at least nails coats of nail polish!
column8: Yeah, sounds like something I should definitely do.

column1: Can you help me do an internet search?
column2: Sure. What do you want to find?
column3: I want to find information on World War Two.
column4: Well, can you be more specific? There are a lot of websites about that.
column5: Yes, I want to know about the Normandy Landing.
column6: Ok. Well, go to www.google.com, and type in Normandy Landing.
column7: Oh, wow! There are lot of sites.
column8: Here, try this one. It's a good site about Normandy Landing.
column9: Thanks.
column10: For detailed information, however, you should read a history book.
column11: Thanks. If I am interested, I'll go to the library.

column1: Excuse me, Supen.

column3: Please forgive me, but I have to leave. I feel terrible. but...
column4: What's the matter?
column5: My daughter isn't feeling well.
column6: Oh, no. Is it serious?
column7: I don't know. Will you forgive me?
column8: Of course. I'm sorry for your daughter.

column1: you are dressed to kill. You look gorgeous, Alexander.
column2: thanks. This is my power suit. I have a dinner date tonight.
column3: how did you meet each other?
column4: she's a friend of Amy. We met at Amy's birthday party.
column5: is this your first date?
column6: yes. I hope it pans out. Cross your fingers, Lily.
column7: sure it will. Oh, no, it's seven fifteen already. I'm going to be late for my date.
column8: oh... so you buried the hatchet with Steven?
column9: absolutely not! He's a cheater. I will never talk to him again. I'm over with him. He's history!
column10: then who will you meet tonight?
column11: a guy I met on the internet three month ago.
column12: really? Are you sure this is a good idea?
column13: please don't be so fussy! I didn't just meet him yesterday.
column14: I know, but remember to meet in a public place and don't give out your personal information.

column1: When are we leaving for our field trip?
column2: Our science field trip is next Monday at 8 a. m. in the morning. Can you mark that on your calendar?
column3: Yes, I will write that down.
column4: That will be Monday, December 2nd. We need to start loading the buses half an hour early, so plan to arrive at 7.
column5: Yes, I will be there on time.
column6: We will return 6 days later on December 8th. Will someone be picking you up?
column7: Yes, someone is coming to get me.
column8: The return bus will leave the campground at 5 p. m. and return to campus 3 hours later at 8 p. m.
column9: What should we bring with us?
column10: I am going to post all of that information on the geology club web page. Check it out when you get a chance. See you Monday!

column1: Mom, I hate eating vegetables!
column2: You don ’ t have to eat them. I don ’ t mind.
column3: Thanks, Mom.Can I have dessert now? I love chocolate cake.
column4: No dessert for you unless you eat all of your vegetables.
column5: But I don ’ t like them.It ’ s not fair.
column6: You can have some fruits for dessert.If you eat an apple and a banana, I might let you have a small piece of chocolate cake.
column7: Ok, actually I don ’ t mind eating peas and carrots.But I hate broccoli and cauliflower.
column8: I'll remember that for next time.You ’ ll get extra peas and carrots, but no broccoli or cauliflower, ok?
column9: Thanks, Mom!

column1: How is the college search going?
column2: It's a huge headache. I have no idea what I want to do.
column3: But don't you want to study music? Shouldn't it be easy?
column4: It should be, but there are too many options. My grades are good enough that I have a lot of choices, but after that...
column5: I know. You have to decide if you want to attend a school in a city or in the country, a big school or a small school, a public or private school...
column6: Yup, you understand. And my parents are trying to pressure me into going to a Catholic college. They both attended one and think that it combines a good education with good discipline. And the tuition 3 is usually pretty low.
column7: I see. Well, don't forget to talk to the college counselor at the school. He usually gives good advice and can help point you in the right direction.He gave me some information, and next week I'm going to take a look at some of the colleges he recommended.
column8: Thanks for the information. And good luck in your college search.

column1: Can you be serious for a moment, we've been dating for 6 months now, I really like you. I'd like to take a relationship to the next level.
column2: So what are you trying to say to me?
column3: It feels like you are not dedicate to our relationship. It seems like you treat it as a just casual dating.
column4: How should I say it?
column5: I don't want to be like this. I think we should get step further.
column6: It has only been 6 months, our relationship hasn't had a chance to maturate. We are still have some hurdle we have to jump over.
column7: Like what?
column8: Last week I saw Brain kissing you on the cheek.
column9: It was only the cheek.
column10: That is ok, then? Starts on the cheek? pretty soon you french kiss in the back on his car.
column11: Oh, that is ridiculous.
column12: So is it ok if I kiss other women on the cheek?
column13: Definitely not.
column14: You see, we still have hurdle.

column1: I want to go try on these clothes.

column3: I found some jeans, and a new blouse.
column4: Go and try it on.
column5: What do you think?
column6: I love that shirt on you.
column7: What about the jeans?
column8: They don't really fit you right.
column9: I don't think so either.
column10: That blouse is absolutely wonderful on you though.
column11: Well, I'll just buy the shirt.
column12: That would be a good idea.

column1: Let ’ s see if we can reach some sort of agreement over your curfew.
column2: Ok, every one asks their parents let them stay out until 2 or 3 in the morning.
column3: Well, I ’ m not everyone-else ’ s father. I think you need be in the house by ten o ’ clock.
column4: That ’ s absurd. I know some junior high kids who can stay out later than that.
column5: I ’ ll be worried if you stay out late.
column6: Ok, how about midnight curfew. and I'll let you know where I am.

column2: Oh, yes, I am. I have always wanted to go to the States. I love meeting new people. And making new friends.
column3: Well, I'm sure you will.
column4: Well, there's one thing.
column5: What's the matter
column6: I'm a little worried about my host family. You know, in the agreement I have to do some cooking for them.

column2: What does it say?
column3: A lot of things. There is a part about how old people should accept being old and stop feeling restless. You really should read it.
column4: Thank you. But I don't think I'll bother.
column5: Why not? What this article says makes good sense to me. If you read it, I'm sure you'll agree with me.
column6: I don't think I'll have any trouble with getting old. But perhaps you can keep the article for a while, I may read it later.

column1: Peter, how often do you exercise?

column4: Well, I don't eat any meat, but I do eat fish and eggs.
column5: Do you eat a lot of vegetables?
column6: Oh yes, and fruit, I love fruit.
column7: What do you drink?
column8: Well, I never drink alcohol, coffee or tea. They are very bad for you.

column4: He's over sixty.

column10: About the same.
column11: Someone will be out to take a look any minute now.

column13: Of course! It's the sort of thing a hospital emergency ward is for. Will we have to wait much longer?
column14: I hope not.It isn't that busy.

column1: May, is this the Hall of Ancient China?

column4: For protection. Some relics will turn to dust if exposed to air.
column5: So there isn't air in the glass boxes?
column6: No, there isn't. They are all vacuumed.
column7: I wonder how old these things are, thousands of years?
column8: Yeah, they all come from a very ancient time.
column9: Hey, look at the three-leg cup. I've seen it on TV.
column10: The bronze cup was made 4,000 years ago. It's priceless!
column11: Yeah, it has no value at all. Who will use this cup today?
column12: Danny, priceless means so valuable that you can't put a price on it.
column13: Oh, it does?

column1: Tonight is a party night! What drinks do you think we need?
column2: Well, not everyone wants to drink beer. Make sure there are some soft drinks and juice. Nothing ’ s as refreshing as iced drinks on a hot day.
column3: I don ’ t think we need too much in the way of soft drinks. Two super bottles of Cola should cover everyone. What about wine?
column4: Just buy a cask of wine. Have you bought ice yet?
column5: No, once I fill the tub with beer, I ’ ll get the ice. The beer will be cool if you put the tub under the ice. The cooler, the better.
column6: I think a bottle of champagne would be a good idea. It ’ s appetizing and tasty.
column7: Well, if you say so. Personally speaking, I ’ d rather die of thirst than drink champagne.

column1: Hello, Kevin.
column2: Oh, hi, Lee. You look great.
column3: Thanks. You too.

column9: Yes, I am aware of them.

column1: Thank you for coming.

column6: How long has the pipe been leaking?
column7: It began leaking a couple of days ago.
column8: I must tell you that in order to get to the pipe, I must tear down that wall.
column9: I know.
column10: That won ’ t be a problem?
column11: Not as long as it gets fixed.
column12: All right, I will start working now.

column2: What? That would be to cut off your nose to spite your face.
column3: Then what shall we do?
column4: Call the police.

column1: I think it's important that all people have the ability to read.
column2: I agree with you, but that's easier said than done.

column4: I'm going to help him.
column5: What's he doing?
column6: He's fixing his roof.

column1: What can I do for you?
column2: I'm looking for the cameras.
column3: They're in Aisle Two.

column1: I got a raise.
column2: I'm glad to hear that.

column1: Mum, pass me some more please!
column2: Tina, you should have more nutritious food. Don't eat these crisps any more.
column3: But the ads say they're most nutritious.
column4: Have you ever heard the ads say anything bad about their products?

column1: If I won the Pools, I'd go round the world.
column2: Would you? I wouldn't.
column3: What would you do?
column4: Oh, I don't know. I'd buy a big house with a garden for my wife and kids, I suppose. But it's difficult to imagine having a lot of money.
column5: One thing's certain. If I had a lot of money, I wouldn't work any more.
column6: Wouldn't you? What would you do with all that spare time?
column7: As I said, I'd go round the world.
column8: What would you do after that?
column9: Oh, I don't know. It'd take me a long time to go round the world.
column10: It doesn't sound very exciting.
column11: Anyway, we haven't won the Pools, and we're not likely to win them. So there isn't much point in talking about it, is there?
column12: I'd be happy if I got a rise.
column13: And my wife would be happy if I bought her a mink coat.
column14: Well, I'm not likely to get a rise and you haven't the money for a mink coat, so let's come down to earth and have another drink.
column15: What'll you have?
column16: I'll have a pint of the best.
column17: I'd have a Scotch if I were you. We deserve it.
column18: All right. Make it a double, will you?

column1: Have we handed out all the water?
column2: Yes. So what else to do now?
column3: Nothing. The teacher said the only thing left was to get back all the disposable cups later.
column4: I see. How do you like the game?
column5: Terrific. There is one girl said, It is the best game I've ever watched.
column6: Who do you think do better?
column7: Clive was really outstanding. Not only he put on a big show himself, but also he inspired the whole team.
column8: Exactly. He is unbelievable.
column9: On the other hand, I think the other team won everyone's respect. The leader said they could have crumpled at the beginning, but they just carried on and never lost their cool.
column10: They were really tough.
column11: The thing I like most about them is that they did not play with a heavy heart even though at that time the odds seemed to be against them.
column12: I can't agree more. Okay, time is up. Let's do the last thing.

column1: Are you OK?
column2: Yeah. Why not?
column3: Because... I heard John got married yesterday.
column4: Oh, you went to the wedding?
column5: No, he didn't tell me about it. Don't feel bad.
column6: I'm OK. I promise. Maybe you don't know that I have done with him for a long time.

column2: Sure. Let me get it for you.
column3: Can you also show me this one?
column4: No problem. This one is made of pure gold.
column5: I think the cloisonn bracelet is more beautiful.
column6: You ’ re right. This one costs less, but is more beautiful.
column7: Will the luster fade out after some time?
column8: No, we guarantee the quality.
column9: Ok. Can I try it on?
column10: Certainly, the mirror is right here.

column1: I'm terribly sorry to have caused you so much trouble.
column2: That's all right.

column1: Good evening, sir. What's your pleasure this evening? Your usual?
column2: Yes. I'm going to stay with the same, a beer.
column3: Certainly, a beer. Here you are, sir.
column4: Oh, darn. Look what I've done. ( Spill the drink )
column5: Don't worry. I'll make you another on the house.

column1: I ’ Ve got a new boss.
column2: Oh, what ’ s he like?
column3: Well, he ’ s got dark hair and brown eyes.
column4: Yes.
column5: And a white sports car.
column6: Um, that ’ s good.
column7: Yes, but he ’ s got a wife and 3 children as well.

column3: We ate a lot of things. We played games and gave gifts to Jessie. We had a lot of fun.
column4: You were really lucky.
column5: My birthday comes next month. I want to hold a birthday party, too.
column6: I hope I can go to your party.

column2: Cloudy in the morning, overcast in the afternoon.
column3: Any rain?
column4: No, but I wouldn't be surprised if it rained tomorrow.
column5: I wouldn't either. It's been looking like rain for several days.

column1: Well, you know how important a clean house is to your grandma.
column2: Yes, I hear about it every time she comes here.
column3: She was the head janitor at St. Mary's Hospital for thirty years, after all.
column4: I think she misses that job and wants to take it out on us.
column5: You know, maybe she's just a neat freak.
column6: I think she just likes to make us miserable.
column7: You could be right.

column3: How long until you're finished?

column5: I like my hair so much.
column6: Do you really?
column7: It's beautiful.
column8: Well, thank you very much.
column9: How much is it for my hair?
column10: You owe me $ 55.
column11: Thanks for everything.

column1: Good afternoon. I've brought the extra blanket you asked for.
column2: Oh, thank you.
column3: Is there anything I can do for you now?
column4: Yes. I'm rather tired and want to go to bed early. Please make the bed.
column5: Certainly, sir.

column6: There won't be many other expenses expect food.

column8: Sounds good.
column9: In addition, they are waterproof and shockproof.

column11: We guarantee the quality of the product for 12 months. We also provide a worldwide warranty.
column12: How much does the pair cost?
column14: It is a bit expensive. But it is worth buying one's favorite. I will take them.

column1: What are your plans for this weekend?

column3: If the weather's fine.
column4: I am sure it will be. It's been good so far this weekend.
column5: I know a good place to hire bikes if you want.

column1: Hello?
column2: Hi Tina, It's Joe.
column3: Hi Joe.
column4: How's the weather there today?

column7: It's 30 degrees now. It was even colder this morning.

column9: I was watching the news a little earlier. They said it's probably going to snow tomorrow.
column10: I really don't like the winter. I wish it were summer.
column11: Me too. How's the weather where you are?
column12: It's not too bad, but it's pretty cold here too. It was about 45 today and it rained this afternoon. I heard it's going to be a little warmer tomorrow.

column1: Okay, Doctor, tell it to me straight.
column2: If you want to live much longer you have to give up smoking.
column3: I've tried before. Everything I've tried doesn't work.
column4: Maybe with the choice of life or death before you, you will find it easier.
column5: May I see that x-ray again?
column6: See all these black areas? That's tar built up in your Lungs.
column7: And that is what's causing my shortness of breath.
column8: Look at it this way, when you quit, you will save money, time and your life!

column1: What's this city famous for?
column2: Tea and silk.
column3: Where can we have the famous tea?
column4: Preferably at the big department stores.
column5: Thank you.

column1: Have you ever thought about having children, Kaitlyn?
column2: My husband and I have thought about it, but we've decided not to have any. They're just too expensive. Besides, with all the news about global warming on the news lately, who knows what kind of Worl
column3: Well, I've always wanted to have lots of children. Growing up with only one brother, I always felt a bit lonely. What do you think about families with only one child?
column4: For me, growing up in a big family always made me yearn for attention. I always wanted to be an only child so that I could always do what I wanted and so that I wouldn't ever have to share.
column5: Don't you think you would miss having other people around?
column6: No way! I spent 20 years of my life with relatives around me 24-7. You know, I don't think I've ever actually spent any time by myself in my parents' home. What do you think fo the one-child policy
column7: If China didn't have such a policy, can you imagine how many people there would be in China now?
column8: That's true. But as a woman, I'm glad that even though I don't want any children, I at least have a choice in how many children I have. On the other hand, I can't imagine what China would be like
column9: Do you think most families with many children envy or feel sorry for other families with only one child?
column10: I don't know what other people think, but I, for one, envy only children!

column1: Today more and more people advocate lifelong learning. But people have different views about lifelong learning. How do you understand lifelong learning?
column2: I think lifelong learning is the concept that it's never too soon or too late for learning
column3: Does that mean studying all the time?
column4: I don't think so. I think it's about your attitude towards learning. One should be open to new ideas, decisions, skills or behaviors.
column5: Then the axiom -' You can't teach an old dog new tricks' doesn't work any longer.
column6: You're right. Lifelong learning is about finding learning opportunities at all ages and in numerous contexts
column7: Yes, I agree with you. When I retired I will participate in programs to keep momentally active.
column8: Me too. To keep up with the changing world, one must be involved in lifelong learning and be ready to accept new things.

column11: Yes, so I want to learn French to develop my career.

column1: There are so many environment problems in the world today. Do you think we can really solve them all or will destroy the world?
column2: I hope that world leaders can get together and agree on a plan for action, but I doubt it ’ ll happen before it ’ s too late.
column3: We need to solve the problem of air pollution before we destroy the atmosphere. There ’ s lots of clean, modern technology, but companies in developed countries say it ’ s expensive. Developing countries put more emphasis on economic development than on environment protection.
column4: Everyone is looking at the issue in the short term, rather than the long term. It ’ s the same with the destruction of the rainforests. Countries and companies just want the wood. They ’ re not thinking about the long-term damage to the forests. We should also remember that the forests are an important natural habitat for thousands of species of animal and plant life.
column5: In other parts of the world, especially in Africa, there is a problem with desertification. Climate change and over-farming are causing farmland to turn into desert. In means that people cannot grow enough food.
column6: It also means that people sometimes fight over the famp 3land that remains. Damaging the environment actually leads to conflict between people.
column7: Have you ever thought about joining an organization committed to protecting the environment? You could get involved with projects to improve the environment.
column8: I think I ’ d like to do that. I could take the things I learn here back to my country when I have finished my studies.

column1: I heard that you finished my home inspection, and I was wondering how it went.

column5: Wouldn ’ t the owners have told me about any problems?
column6: Sellers aren ’ t always truthful, and there might also be problems that they aren ’ t aware of.

column8: You can make the sale of the house contingent on them fixing the problems.

column4: What happened?
column5: Well, three people are celebrating their birthdays this month and the policy here is for everyone to contribute ten dollars to a card and cake for each person.
column6: Wow, so you'll be out thirty dollars on your first week at work!

column8: Well, every department is different. You wouldn't want your new co-workers to think you're a Grinch, right?
column9: What is that?
column10: A Grinch is a person who spoils the mood at a happy occasion by being selfish or unenthusiastic. You know - a party proper.
column11: I definitely don't want to be that! But, I still think it's unreasonable for them to ask me for such a big sum of money when we don't know each other very well. What should I do?
